The style name probably refers to the prolific folk composers Johann and Josef Schrammel - and 'schrammeln' is the German term for 'strumming'.

Cox was the member of parliament representing the constituency of Batley & Spen in West Yorkshire who was murdered in June 2016 during the lead-in to the UK referendum on European Union membership. She supported the UK remaining a member of the Union.

name: Brooke Annibale

name: Harry Hudson

name: Micky Ashman
comments: Bass player and former member of the Chris Barber Band. He first played with Chris Barber in one of the latter’s amateur bands in the early 1950s. By 1955 Micky had turned professional and was working in Humphrey Lyttelton’s band. In 1956 he joined Chris Barber once more. Micky played on just two albums with Chris Barber’s Jazz Band. He left the Barber band following the departure of Lonnie Donegan in 1956 joining Lonnie in what came to be one of the most popular musical acts in the UK in the late 1950s. In the early 1960s he was leading his own outfit: Micky Ashman’s Ragtime Jazzmen.

name: Debbie Duncan

name: Donny McCaslin
comments: American jazz saxophonist, who became internationally known since he - in November 2014 - played tenor and soprano saxophone on David Bowie's single "Sue (Or in a Season of Crime)". Subsequently Bowie recruited a local New York jazz combo led by McCaslin as the backing band for the sessions of his last album ★ (Blackstar) which was released on January 8, 2016 .

name: Albert Hamilton

He played with Carson Robison on records and radio for over twelve years. He also recorded prolifically with his group, Frank Novak and His Rootin' Tootin' Boys.

name: Joe Brannelly

Born in Boston, Massachusetts in 1900, Joe toured the US as a youngster in a boy’s band playing both the banjo and fiddle. He moved to London in 1923, where his banjo playing was in much demand, initially with the Boston Orchestra, then with London’s Savoy Havana Band and later with The Rhythm Maniacs and Ambrose & His Orchestra. Joe left Ambrose's band in 1938 to become a successful music publisher.

In 1959 Ahinora left Communist Bulgaria by contracting a marriage in name only with a German.

name: Reginald Foresythe
comments: British jazz pianist, arranger, composer and bandleader. Foresythe played piano from age eight and worked in the second half of the 1920s as a pianist and accordionist in dance bands in Paris, Australia, Hawaii, and California. He also wrote music for films by D.W. Griffith among others and played in Paul Howard's Quality Serenaders. In 1930 Foresythe moved to Chicago. He spent much of his career on the dance band scene in Britain later serving in the Royal Air Force during World War II and working as an accompanist to vocalists and a solo pianist in London in the 1950s.

name: Dotty Mack

New Mayfair Dance Orchestra conducted by Ronnie Munro
Ronnie Munro and His Dance Orchestra

Later he became musical director of HMV's house orchestra (The New Mayfair Orchestra), composing and arranging extensively for Jack Hylton, Lew Stone, Percival Mackey, Henry Hall and Ambrose. He used a variety of pseudonyms on record including: The Roof Garden Orchestra, The Merton Orchestra, Parlophone Syncopaters, West End Players and many others.

name: Josh Garrels

There were only two pressings of the album (500 each) and Pearlman hand-distributed them throughout California for a couple of years, even leaving copies on college campuses

name: Phil Pearlman
comments: Leader of "Beat Of The Earth", an experimental psychedelic jam band from Orange County, California in 1967. Later founded "Relatively Clean Rivers". In all Pearlman made four indie records between 1965 and 1976. The first one was a 45 rpm parody of surf-hot-rod songs by "Phil & The Flakes".

name: Leon Jessel

Today he is best known internationally as the composer of the popular jaunty march "Parade der Zinnsoldaten" (The Parade of the Tin Soldiers, also known as The Parade of the Wooden Soldiers). Jessel was a prolific composer who wrote hundreds of light orchestral pieces, piano pieces, songs, waltzes, mazurkas, marches, choruses, and other salon music.

name: Jimmy Leach
aliases: Jimmy Leach and His New Organolians
comments: Pianist and organist from Stockport. Jimmy Leach and his Organolians were regulars on BBC radio's "Music While You Work" programmes during the 1940s and 1950s.  The Organolians' records sold well on the Columbia label where Jimmy began recording in 1939. More than 30 Columbia 78s have been listed issued from 1945 to 1953 (there were others issued during the war years). Vocalists are featured on some sides including Cyril Shane, Alan Dean, Johnny Johnston, Rita Williams, Leslie Douglas - and on occasion - Jimmy Leach himself.

Trivia: 'Snopp' in Swedish was a common word for 'brush', but turned into an inoffensive expression for 'penis', so Snopporna (= the ...) was quite a daring name for an early 1960s young ladies group.

name: Dmitry Kabalevsky

He was a prolific composer of piano music and chamber music; many of his piano works have been performed by Vladimir Horowitz. He is probably best known in the rest of the world for the "Comedians' Galop" from "The Comedians Suite", Op. 26.

In the 1930s he joined the NSB, the fascist National Socialist Party of the Netherlands. In the Second World War he continued touring throughout Europe,  expressed racist opinions about Jews and black people and performed at the parties of important Nazi officials. Resistance groups broadcast his famous "Ständchen" with the following last lyrics: "Verkoopt zijn Volk en Vaderland voor zes losse centen" (Sells his people and homeland for six cents). He died in prison in Hilversum a few months after the war ended.

Together with her sister Gabrielle  - a famous soprano - they made guest appearances in Warsaw (1897), Berlin, Vienna, Budapest, London and Prague. In the 1899-1903 seasons she appeared at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow. In 1904 she sang in Magdeburg and Leipzig. In 1906 she performed in St. Petersburg and Moscow .

She made her debut in St. Petersburg in 1892, where she remained for the remainder of her career. From 1901 until 1914 she made many recordings for Berliner Gramophone, Pathé, Columbia, Lyrophone and Beka, all in St. Petersburg.

Their early version of the Bach-Gounod Ave Maria (GC 03033) was recorded twice: in October 1904 and again in February 1905. And this recording was one of the great early classics of the gramophone.

comments: Renowned Latin percussionist. He is the son of Walfredo De Los Reyes II, a famed Cuban trumpet player and singer, and the father of percussionists Walfredo De Los Reyes, Jr. and Daniel De Los Reyes. Some confusion may arise from the fact that in the earlier years of his career, while his father (Walfredo De Los Reyes II) was still active, he is often credited as Walfredo De Los Reyes, Jr. to distinguish him from his father, the trumpet player. Recordings credited to Walfredo De Los Reyes, Jr., dating from the 1940s through the early 1960s are most certainly Walfredo De Los Reyes, Sr. and not his son.
